Trump appoints leader of his Secret Service detail to head agency President Donald Trump said Wednesday that he is appointing Sean Curran — the special agent in charge of Trump’s security detail who shielded him during an assassination attempt at a Pennsylvania campaign rally last year — to serve as the next U.S. Secret Service director. “Sean has distinguished himself as a brilliant leader, who is capable of directing and leading operational security plans for some of the most complex Special Security Events in the History of our Country, and the World,” Trump wrote in a post on his social media platform, Truth Social. “He proved his fearless courage when he risked his own life to help save mine from an assassin’s bullet in Butler, Pennsylvania. I have complete and total confidence in Sean to make the United States Secret Service stronger than ever before.” Curran is widely respected for his rigor and skills as a protective detail agent and supervisor, growing extremely close to Trump after serving as the agent in charge of his detail for the past four years. It was Curran, however, who approved assigning a junior detail agent with minimal experience to prepare the security plan for the campaign visit to Butler, a plan that failed to address basic security protocols and allowed a would-be assassin a clear shot at Trump from higher ground. Trump’s appointment of Curran will hearten some longtime agents but also ignores the recommendations of multiple expert panels who have studied the Secret Service’s security failures and recommended fresh leadership from outside the agency. Trump is following a long line of presidents before him by naming a key member of his protection team as the agency’s director, rather than choosing someone outside the Secret Service to give it fresh leadership who can revamp and harden its approach to protection.
